body:
Yes, intentionally that function supports Nvim favor of Lua only (you can see it uses `vim.loader`, which is specific in Nvim Lua environment). If you read `news-0.11.txt`, you'll also see it says that `gf` in Lua buffers can go to Lua modules in `'runtimepath'` and `'packpath'`, which should implies that the feature is made for Nvim-specific Lua.

I also wrote an `'includeexpr'` for general Lua in `$VIMRUNTIME/ftplugin/lua.vim`, you can copy it to your config in `after/` directory if you want Vim behavior. Anyway, that Vimscript function has never been made default `'includeexpr'` for Lua in any Nvim's stable release.

Nvim is the only environment I write Lua for, so I'm not sure how I could satisfy both Lua developers and people who only use Lua to configure Nvim. Please share your ideas to improve the `'includeexpr'` in `lua.lua`.

so this is a regression?



> not sure how I could satisfy both Lua developers and people who only use Lua to configure Nvim.

Can it try multiple path permutations? If a path exists with/without `lua/` or whatever, it should always be found. The only tricky part is deciding a *tie breaker* situation. it should never fail to find something that exists. 

(And when trying 'path' permutations, it's "first wins".)

> so this is a regression?

It's a regression, yes. If the solution as is stands now is what we want, it should've been marked breaking change in news-0.11.txt, right now it's under "New Features".

> you can copy it to your config in after/ directory if you want Vim behavior. 

I'm aware, and I have for the moment done that to workaround the poor new default behaviour of `gf` in lua files. The new includeexpr has broken the ability to use 'path' option, as it doesn't even consult that user option when trying to find a module.

> It's a regression, yes.

@craigmac It is not. The includeexpr for Lua that Neovim inherited from Vim had never even worked until I sent this patch https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/32680. However, that patch has never had a chance to be default in any stable release of Nvim because just 2 weeks later, this PR https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/32719 was merged

> The new includeexpr has broken the ability to use 'path' option, as it doesn't even consult that user option when trying to find a module.

It doesn't break `'path'`, `gf` always tries `'path'`, `'suffixesadd'` before it even looks at `'includeexpr'`. If it doesn't, then it's a bug in `gf`, not in `'includeexpr'`

In your repro step, you `set path+=plugins/`, but you require the module as `require('plugins.gohere')`. Of that that would not and has never worked in Nvim (it works in Vim, but that's not related to the `'path'` option that includes `'plugins/'`). If you want Nvim to be able to locate file `plugins/gohere.lua` with `set path+=plugins/`, you should just `require('gohere')`

Edit: I will send a PR that merges the behavior of the Lua includeexpr in Vimscript to the Lua function
@craigmacr try setting path to `set path=**,,.` and set your working dir correctly to the project / root

> @craigmacr try setting path to set path=**,,. and set your working dir correctly to the project / root

That's not the problem, the problem is that Nvim's Lua includeexpr only supports the Nvim convention of Lua modules.

> > @craigmacr try setting path to set path=**,,. and set your working dir correctly to the project / root
> 
> That's not the problem, the problem is that Nvim's Lua includeexpr only supports the Nvim convention of Lua modules. Of course that is neither breaking change nor regression, as I explained above.

Yeah, upon checking again, i forgot i have my own includeexpr implementatin for lua fts, that is more lenient in that regard. Disabling the includeexpr and using a path with relative cwd with `** and ,,`, should allow OP to open stuff `/lua` and `/plugins` because according to OP his path was set to only `path+=/plugins`. By default path includes `,,` so not sure if `+=/plugins` is even needed.

issue.title: fix(runtime): 'includeexpr' with non-Nvim-style Lua modules

repository.name: neovim
repository.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability

issue.body:
